titleStmt.title: Description of Free Library of Philadelphia, Lewis E 43: Biblical commentary
titleStmt.funder: Council on Library and Information Resources

notesStmt.note: May be from the same scriptorium as Lewis E 47 and 188; all three are on laid paper with the watermark of a bull's head surmounted by a rose; scripts are similar and decorated initials are identical in style; all are ruled in brown ink for columns, but not for lines
The remains of an insect are present in the right outer margin of fol. 113.
De Ricci, Seymour, with the assistance of W. J. Wilson, Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada, vol. 2 (New York,: H. W. Wilson, 1935-40), p. 2048, no. 130.

Free Library of Philadelphia, A Descriptive Catalogue of the John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts in the Free Library of Philadelphia, compiled by Edwin Wolf, 2nd, with an introduction by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach (Philadelphia: The Free Library, 1937), p. 50, no. 43.

msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This manuscript contains a fifteenth-century commentary on the Epistles of Saint Paul written by the theologian Nicholas of Lyra (1270-1340), who taught at the Sorbonne in Paris in the early fourteenth century.

msItem.title: Epistles of Saint Paul
msItem.incipit: Ecce descripsi tibi eam tripli[citer]. Prov. 22. Quod v[er]bum de sapie[nte] desc[ri]pt[i]o[n]e d[icitu]r . . .
msItem.explicit: D[omino] n[ost]ri ih[es]u [Christi] Cui est honor et gl[ori]am s[e]c[u]la secularum. Amen.

msItem.title: Table for the readings for Sundays and Feast Days

support.watermark: Bull's head surmounted by a rose--Briquet No. 14, 777 ?

supportDesc.extent: ii+147+ii; 313 x 210 mm bound to 325 x 225 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

p.catchwords: Horizontal, lower right corner verso; fols. 11, 23, 35, 47, 59, 71, 85, 97, 109, 119, 133

layoutDesc.layout: Frame-ruled in ink in two columns of 42-45 lines, catena format with scriptural excerpts underlined in red; running headings in red, upper center margin; written area: 240 x 155 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: One large pen-flourished initial; smaller initials in red; manicules in red
147vInscription, "Ad usum Fratris Joachim Guerrini de Montfegatesio O.S.F. Winstediae Mens. Februarii A.D. 1873"

binding.p: Nineteenth-century German black calf with blind-tooled lattice pattern and stamps of lyres; pink paper pastedowns and endpapers; blind stamps of a crown along the spine; stamped in gold on spine: "EPISTOLAE PAULI CUM GLOSSA [LY]RA."

history.provenance: Brother Joachim Guerrinus de Montefegatesio, O.S.F., Winsted, Conn. Feb. 1873, (former librarian of Saint Bonaventura College, Saint Bonaventure, N.Y.), Rev. John Wright; John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936; Inscription of the verso of the last leaf: "Ad usum Fratris Joachim Guerrini de Montfegatesio O.S.F. Winstediae Mens. Februarii A.D. 1873"; Ex libris of Rev. John Wright on front pastedown; American (or English) sale entry pasted on front pastedown
